characters: SIGN FOR THE GOLD EAGLE CLEANERS
A HAND RAPPING AT A DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The flakes drift lazily down toward us. Our angle looks s up. Now an angle looking steeply down: the snow falls not qui away to collect on a foreground chimneypot and on the little shtetl street tha maplike below us. It is night, and quiet, and the street is deserted except one man who walks away from us, his valenki squeaking in the fresh snow. He carries b branches on one shoulder and has a hatchet tucked into his belt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut down to street level. The man walks toward us, bea and bundled against the cold. Smiling, he mutters in Yiddish-the dialogue subtitl

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What a marvel... what a marvel...

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE INTERIOR
dialogues.text: As its door opens and the man enters.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Dora!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man crosses to the stove with his bundle of wood. The continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 . Can you help me with the ice? The man dumps the wood into a box by the stove as his wif with an ice pick. . I expected you hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You can't imagine what just happened. I was coming back on the Lublin road when the wheel came off the cart thank heavens it was the way back and I'd already sold th geese!

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: How much?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Fifteen groshen, but that's not the story. I was struggli set the cart upright when a droshky approaches from the direction of Lvov. How lucky, you think, that someone is out this late.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Yes, very remarkable.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: But that's the least of it! He stops to help me; we talk this, we talk of that-it turns out this is someone you kn Traitle Groshkover!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His wife stares at him as he beams. He takes the stare as a sign that she can't place the nam . You know, REB GROSHKOVER! Pesel Bunim's uncle! The chacham from Lodz, who studied under the Zohar reb in Krakow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still she stares. Then, quietly:

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: God has cursed us.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Traitle Groshkover has been dead for three years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laughter erupts from the man but, as his wife continues t at him, he strangles on it. Quiet. Wind whistles under the eaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Why do you say such a thing! I saw the man! I talked to h

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: You talked to a dybbuk. Traitle Groshkover died of typhus in Pesel Bunim's house. Pesel told me-she sat shiva for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each through a silence broken only by the s of the quickening wind. A rap at the door. Neither immediately responds. Finally, to her husband:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: For some soup, to warm himself. The wind moans. He helped me, Dora!

dialogues.speaker: THE DOOR
dialogues.text: We are looking in from the outside as it unlatches and cr in, opened by the husband in the foreground, who has arranged his face into a strai look of greeting. In the background the wife stares, hollow-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: REB GROSHKOVER! You are welcome here! Reverse on REB GROSHKOVER: a short, merry-looking fellow a bifurcated beard and a silk hat and spectacles. He gives a little squeal of deli

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: You are too kind, Velvel! Too kind!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the house and sees the wife staring at him. And you must be Dora! So much I have heard of you! Yes, your cheeks are pink and your legs are stout! What a wife you have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The husband chuckles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Yes! A ray of sun, a ray of sun! Sit!

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: My husband said he offered you soup.

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: Yes, but I couldn't possibly eat this late, or I'd have nightmares. No, no: no soup for me!

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REB GROSHKOVER laughs.

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: I see! You think I'm fat enough already!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He settles, chuckling, into his chair, but Dora remains s

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: No. A dybbuk doesn't eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 REB GROSHKOVER stares at her, shocked. The wife returns the stare. The husband looks from wife to REB GROSHKOVER, apprehensi A heavy silence. REB GROSHKOVER bursts into pealing laughter.

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: What a wife you have!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes away tears of merriment; the husband relaxes, ev to smile.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I assure you, REB GROSHKOVER, it's nothing personal; she heard a story you had died, three years ago, at Pesel Bunim's house. This is why she think you are a dybbuk; I, of course, do not believe in such things. I am a rational man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REB GROSHKOVER is still chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: Oh my. Oh my yes. What nonsense. And even if there were spirits, certainly... He thumps his chest. I am not one of them!

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Pesel always worried. Your corpse was left unattended for many minutes when Pesel's father broke shiva and left the room-it must have been then that the Evil One- She breaks off to spit at the mention of the Evil One. -took you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REB GROSHKOVER is terribly amused:

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: "My corpse!" Honestly! What a wife you have!

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Oh yes? Look, husband...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps forward to the Reb, who looks enquiringly up at They were preparing the body. Pesel's father shaved one check...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As his eyes roll down to look at her hand, she draws it a his smooth right cheek. Then he left the room. He came back, and shaved the other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reaches across to the other cheek, REB GROSHKOVER's e following her hand- You were already gone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -and drags her hand across. A bristly sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REB GROSHKOVER laughs.

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: I shaved hastily this morning and missed a bit-by you thi makes me a dybbuk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He appeals to the husband: It's true, I was sick with typhus when I stayed with Peselle, but I recovered, as you can plainly see, and now I-hugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wife steps back. REB GROSHKOVER looks slowly down at his own chest in whic wife has just planted an ice pick. REB GROSHKOVER stares at the ice pick. The wife stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 The husband stares. Suddenly, REB GROSHKOVER bursts out laughing: What a wife you have! The husband can manage only a shocked whisper:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Woman, what have you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REB GROSHKOVER again looks down at his chest, which again him to laughter. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: Why would she do such a thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up. I ask you, Velvel, as a rational man: which of us is possessed?

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: What do you say now about spirits? He is unharmed!

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: On the contrary! I don't feel at all well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And indeed, blood has begun to soak through his vest. He chuckles with less energy. One does a mitzvah and this is the thanks one gets?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Dora! Woe, woe! How can such a thing be!

dialogues.speaker: REB GROSHKOVER
dialogues.text: Perhaps I will have some soup. I am feeling weak...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises to his feet but totters. Or perhaps I should go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8 He smiles weakly at Dora.. One knows when one isn't wanted. He walks unsteadily to the door, opens it with some effor staggers out into the moaning wind and snow to be swallowed by the night. The wife and husband stare at the door banging in the win

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Dear wife. We are ruined. Tomorrow they will discover the body. All is lost.

dialogues.speaker: WIFE
dialogues.text: Nonsense, Velvel... She walks to the door... Blessed is the Lord. Good riddance to evil and shuts it a the wind.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: A drumbeat thumps in the black. Music blares: the Jefferson Airplane. Grace Slick's voice When the truth is found to be lies And all the hope inside you dies Don't you want somebody to love. . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An image fades in slowly, but even up full it is dim: som of round, dull white shape with a small black pinhole center. This white half-globe plug set in a flesh-toned field. The flesh tone glows translucently, backlit. We ar toward the white plug and, as we do so, the music grows louder still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 9 A pull back-a reverse on the preceding push in-from the c white plastic earpiece of a transistor radio. The Jefferson Airplane continues o the cut but becomes extremely compressed. The pull back reveals that the earp is lodged in someone's ear and trails a white cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We drift down the cord to find the radio at its other end we do so we hear, live in the room, many voices speaking a foreign language in unison. apparently. The radio is on a desktop but hidden from in front by the held open before it. The book is written in non-Roman characters. We are in Hebrew school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy who is listening to the transistor radio-DANNY Go at a hinge-topped desk in a cinderblock classroom whose rows of desks are o by other boys and girls of about twelve years of age. It is dusk and the ro flourescent-lit. At the front of the room a gray-haired man in a worn suit tie addresses the class. DANNY straightens one leg so that he may dig into a pocke an eye on the TEACHER to make sure he isn't being watched, he eases something out: A twenty-dollar bill.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Mee yodayah? Reuven? Rifkah? Mah zeh "anakim"? Efsheh mashooach ba-avodah?

dialogues.speaker: A BLINDING LIGHT
dialogues.text: At the cut to the light the Jefferson Airplane music jump full. The light resolves into a multi-flared image of a blinking eye. Reverse: the inside of a human ear. Fleshy whorls finely a cavity receding to dark. Objective on the DOCTOR's office: the DOCTOR is peering t a lightscope into the ear of an early-middle-aged man, LARRY Gopnik. The Jefferson Airplane music continues.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL
dialogues.text: Close on Hebrew characters being scribbled onto the black as the TEACHER talks. The TEACHER, talking. A bored child, staring off. His point-of-view: a blacktopped parking lot with a few o school busses, beyond it a marshy field, and distant suburban bungalows. Close on another child staring at something through droop eyelids. His point-of-view: very close on the face of a classroom We hear its electrical hum. Its red sweep-second hand crawls around the dial ver slowly. DANNY Gopnik hisses:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fagle!.. . The TEACHER drones on, writing on the blackboard. DANNY's flit from the TEACHER to the student sitting kitty-corner in front of him-a husky with shaggy hair. He hasn't heard the prompt. . Fagle! The TEACHER turns from the blackboard and DANNY leans bac front, folding the twenty up small behind his book.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Ahnee rotzeh lalechet habait hakisai. Mee yodayah? Misaviv tamid anachnoo tamid... The clock-watching child, eyelids sinking, is beginning t out of one side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 The light again flaring the lens. Reverse: looking into a pupil. Objective: the DOCTOR looking through his scope into LARR eye.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Mm-hmm.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL
dialogues.text: A bored child is excavating a bugger from his nose. The TEACHER turns back to the chalkboard to circle someth

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Fagle!

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Hamrah oomoh- He interrupts himself briefly to make a couple of phlegm- sounds. He resumes: . Hamrah oomoh meshiach oomshel zal?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR palpates LARRY's midriff, digging his fingers the hairy, baggy flesh. DOCTOR's Voice Uh-huh. We'll do some routine X-rays.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL
dialogues.text: A young girl holds a hank of her bangs in front of her fa separating out individual hairs to examine them for split ends.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Ahnoo ahnoo mah? Mah? Talmidim? D'vorah?

dialogues.speaker: D'VORAH
dialogues.text: Ahnee to yodayah. The TEACHER begins to pace the desk aisles, looking back forth among the students.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Mee yodayah? The bugger-seeker, having succesfully withdrawn a bugger, drapes it over the sharp end of his pencil, to what end we cannot know. DANNY, apprehensively eyeing the TEACHER, slides the twen the transistor radio's cover-sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: X-RAY CONE
dialogues.text: A huge white rubberized cone, pointed directly at us. We hear a rush of static and the DOCTOR's voice filtered a talk-back: DOCTOR's Voice Hold still. Wider: LARRY is in his shorts lying on his back on an exa table covered by a sheet of tissue paper. The X-ray cone is pointed at the middle body. There is a brief sci-fi-like machine hum. It clicks off.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL
dialogues.text: The clock-watching student's head is making descending bo his chest.

dialogues.speaker: TEACHER
dialogues.text: Nefsheh shelach hamilamid-eh?! The TEACHER's circuit of the classroom has taken him arou DANNY. DANNY's book lies face-down on the desk, covering the radio, but white cord snakes out from under it up to his ear. The TEACHER yanks at the cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 13 The cord pops out of its jack and the Jefferson Airplane tinnily from beneath the book of torah stories. The TEACHER lifts the book to expose the jangling radio. Outraged, the TEACHER projects above the music: . Mah zeh? ! Mah zeh? ! Some of the students are singing along; a couple beat rhy on their desks. . Shechet, talmidim! Anachnoo lo cam zeh b'bait sefer! Shechet bivakasha! Three other students join in a chorus:

dialogues.speaker: STUDENTS
dialogues.text: Shechet! Shechet bivakasha! The nodding student's head droops ever lower. Other students join in the chant:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nodding student's chin finally reaches, and settles o chest, and he gives a long snorfling inhale of sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: LARRY, now fully clothed, is seated across from the DOCTO The DOCTOR is looking at his file. He absently taps a cig out of a pack and lights up. He nods as he smokes, looking at the file.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, I-sorry. He holds the pack toward LARRY.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, you're in good health. How're Judith and the kids?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Good. Everyone's good. You know. The DOCTOR takes a long suck.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Good. Daniel must be-what? About to be bar mitzvah?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Two weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Well, mazel tov. They grow up fast, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: TINTED PHOTO PORTRAIT
dialogues.text: The portrait, old, in an ornate gilt frame, is of a middl rabbi with a small neat mustache and round spectacles. He wears a tallis hood-sty a phylactery box is strapped to his forehead. A plaque set into the frame ide the man as Rabbi Minda. Wider shows that the portrait hangs in the Hebrew school office, a white cinderblock room. It is quiet. The only sound is a deep e hum. Just visible behind the principal's desk, upon which is a stack of books and a name plate identifying the occupant as MAR TURCHIK, is the top a man's head-an old man, with a few whispy white hairs where his yarmulka is DANNY, seated opposite, pushes up from his slouch to bett across the desk. We boom up to show more of the principal. He is short. He a white shirt and hoist-up pants that come to just below his armpits. He ha eyeglasses. He fiddles with the transistor radio, muttering:

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Hmm... eh... nu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 He experiments with different dials on the radio. DANNY nervously watches.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: You put the- The old man holds up one hand.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: In ivrit. (In Hebrew)

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Um... The old man looks down at the little earpiece pinched bet two fingers. He examines it as a superstitious native might a Coca-Cola bottle. The source of the electrical hum: a wall clock whose red hand crawls around the dial very, very slowly. The Reb continues to squint at the earpiece. DANNY sighs. He encourages:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, you- The principal's tone is harder:

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: In ivrit! This time his cold look holds until he is sure that the a has registered. He looks back down at the earpiece. We hear the door open. The principal ignores it. An old woman walks slowly in with a teacup chattering on She has thick eyeglasses. She wears thick flesh-colored support hose. S slow, short steps toward the desk. The principal is studying the radio.

dialogues.speaker: PRINCIPAL
dialogues.text: Mneh... The old woman continues to take slow short steps toward h The tableau looks like a performance-art piece. She reaches the desk and sets the teacup down. She summon couple of phlegm- hawking rasps and turns to go. She takes slow short steps toward the door. The principal raises the earpiece experimentally toward h Close on his hairy, wrinkled ear as his trembling fingers in the earpiece. The i f ngers push and wobble and tamp the earpiece into plac and then do some more pushing and wobbling and tamping. The principal keeps DANNY fixed with a stare as his hand drops from his ear, ready to reach back up should the earpiece loosen. .mneh... Satisfied that neither the student nor the earpiece are a to make any sudden moves, he looks down at the radio. He turns a dial. Faintly and tinnily from the earpiece we hear the compres jangle of rock music. The rabbi stares blankly, listening. DANNY slumps, looking warily at the rabbi. The rabbi continues to stare down at the radio. The compr rock music jangles on. The rabbi is expressionless, mouth slightly open, listeni Tableau: anxious student, earplugged spiritual leader. Muffled, from the outer office, the hawking of phlegm.

dialogues.speaker: CLASSROOM
dialogues.text: We are behind a man who writes equations on a chalkboard, at work and hand quickly waggling. Periodically he glances back, giving us look at his face: it is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 17 LARRY Gopnik.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You following this?... Okay?.. So... Heh-heh... This part is exciting... Students follow along, bored. LARRY continues to write. . So, okay. So. So if that's that, then we can do this, right? Is that right? Isn't that right? And that's Schrodinger's paradox, right? Is the cat dead or is the c not dead? Okay?

dialogues.speaker: BLEGEN HALL
dialogues.text: LARRY is entering the physics department office. The depa secretary wheels her castored chair away from her typing.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Messages, Professor Gopnik. He takes the three phone messages.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Natalie. Oh-CLIVE. Come in. A Korean graduate student who was been waiting on a strai chair rises.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: He is flipping through the messages. Absently:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So, uh, what can I do for you? The messages: WHILE YOU WERE OUT Dick Dutton OF Columbia Record Club

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 CALLED. REGARDING: "Please call." WHILE YOU WERE OUT Sy Ableman CALLED. REGARDING "Let's talk." WHILE YOU WERE OUT CLIVE Park CALLED. REGARDING: "Unjust test results." He crumples the last one.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Uh, Dr. Gopnik, I believe the results of Physics Mid-Term were unjust.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, how so?

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: I received an unsatisfactory grade. In fact: F, the faili grade.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh, yes. You failed the mid-term. That's accurate.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Yes, but this is not just. I was unaware to be examined o the mathematics.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well-you can't do physics without mathematics, really, can you.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: If I receive failing grade I lose my scholarship, and fee shame. I understand the physics. I understand the dead ca

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (SURPRISED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You understand the dead cat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 19 CLIVE nods gravely. But... you... you can't really understand the physics without understanding the math. The math tells how it really works. That's the real thing; the stories I give y class are just illustrative; they're like, fables, say, t give you a picture. An imperfect model. I mean-even I don't understand the dead cat. The math is how it really works. CLIVE shakes his head, dubious.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Very difficult... very difficult...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I... I'm sorry, but I... what do you propose?

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Passing grade.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No no, I-

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Or perhaps I can take the mid-term again. Now I know it covers mathematics.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, the other students wouldn't like that, would they. one student gets to retake the test til he gets a grade h likes. CLIVE impassively considers this.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Secret test. LARRY wraps a hand wearily over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . No, I'm afraid-

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Hush-hush.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, that's just not workable. I'm afraid we'll just have bite the bullet on this thing, CLIVE, and-

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Very troubling. He rises. . very troubling... He goes to the door, shaking his head, as LARRY looks on He leaves. LARRY stares at the open door. The secretary outside, her to us, types on. LARRY. looks stupidly around his own office, shakes his h He picks up the phone message from Sy Ableman-"Let's talk dials. As he dials his other hand wanders over the papers on the desktop. There is a plain white envelope on the desk. LARRY picks as the phone rings through. A ring is clipped short and a warm basso-baritone rumbles the line: Phone Voice Sy Ableman.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hello, Sy, LARRY Gopnik.

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: (MOURNFUL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LARRY. How are you, my friend. LARRY picks idly at the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Good, how've you been, Sy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 Inside the envelope: a thick sheaf of one-hundred-dollar

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Oh fine. Shall we talk LARRY. LARRY reacts to the money.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (into phone) What?! Oh! Sorry! I, uh-call back! He slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: . CLIVE
dialogues.text: He rushes out the door, through the secretarial area, and the hallway, and looks up toward the elevators. Empty. He looks at the stuffed envelope he still holds. He goes back to the departmental office. The secretary si She glances at him and, as she goes back to her typing:

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Sy Ableman just called. Said he got disconnected.

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: A hand enters to knock. Man's Voice Out in a minute! SARAH, the sixteen-year-old girl who has just knocked, ro her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I gotta wash my hair! I'm going out tonight!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Out in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ! She stomps down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Judith, a woman of early middle age, is at the stove. SAR

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: W is Uncle Arthur always in the bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: He has to drain his sebacious cyst. You know that. Will you set the table?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Why can't he do it in the basement? Or go out in the garage!

dialogues.speaker: BUS
dialogues.text: We are raking the exterior of an orange school bus as it along. Hebrew characters on the side identify it-to some, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: We are locked down on DANNY as the bus rattles like an ol squeaking, grinding gears, belching exhaust. DANNY and the children around hi and pitch about but, from their lack of reaction, seem used to it. They raise their voices to be heard over the engine noise the various stress noises in the chassis and a transistor radio somewhere that plays J Airplane.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I had twenty bucks in it too. Inside the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 23 Mark Sallerson Twenty bucks! How come.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I bought a lid from Mike Fagle. Couple weeks ago. I still owed him twenty. Mark Sallerson He already gave you the pot?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah but a couple weeks ago my funding got cut off. Fagle said he'd pound the crap out of me if I didn't pay up. Howard Altar What funding got cut off? Where do you get your money? Another boy, with thick glasses, is Ronnie Nudell. Ronnie Nudell What happened? Mark Sallerson Rabbi Turchik took his radio. Had money in it. Ronnie Nudell That fucker!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. I think he said he was confiscating it. Ronnie Nudell He's a fucker! Where do you get your money? Mark Sallerson Mike Fagle's gonna kick his ass. Last week he pounded the crap out of Seth Seddlemeyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24 Ronnie Nudell He's a fucker! Mark Sallerson Fagle? Or Seth Seddlemeyer? Ronnie Nudell They're both f ickers!

dialogues.speaker: BATHROOM DOOR
dialogues.text: A hand enters to knock. Uncle Arthur's Voice Out in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Are you still in there?! Uncle Arthur I, uh.. . Just a minute!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: I've gotta wash my hair! I'm going out tonight, to the ho Uncle Arthur Okay!

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: LARRY pulls into the driveway and gets out of the car. Th of a lawn mower. He looks. His point-of-view: Gar Brandt, the next-door neighbor, is his lawn. He has a buzz cut and is wearing a white T-shirt. Another noise competes with the lawn mower: rattling, squ gear-grinding. The orange school bus with Hebrew lettering pulls up across t Its door opens with a pneumatic hiss to discharge a passenger.

dialogues.speaker: DINNER TABLE
dialogues.text: LARRY sits in. His wife and two children are already seat There is one empty place. LARRY projects:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur! A muffled voice:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yeah!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Dinner!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Okay! Out in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: We should wait.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Are you kidding! They start eating.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Mr. Brandt keeps mowing part of our lawn.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Does that matter?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Is it important? LARRY shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's just odd.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Any news on your tenure?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I think they'll give me tenure.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You think.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (EQUABLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know. These things aren't, you know.. .

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: No, I don't know. Which is why I ask.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Mom, how long is Uncle Arthur staying with us?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Ask your father.

dialogues.speaker: BACK YARD
dialogues.text: Twilight. LARRY is stepping onto a hose as he unwheels it from the of a traveling sprinkler, laying out an are to cover the back yard. Intermittent th from next door: Gar Brandt and his son, who also has a buzz cut and a whi throw a baseball back and forth. Gar Brandt throws hard. The ball pops in boy's mitt.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ow. LARRY walks over to the boundary defined by the fresh mow He sights down it. Gar Brandt looks over his shoulder at LARRY, looking. Gar is expressionless. He

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 goes back to throwing.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Evening. Lights on. LARRY sits at the kitchen table, a br open on the chair next to him. Blue books-examination booklets-are spread on the ta in front of him. He reads, occasionally making marginal scribbles, grading. From off, faint and dulled by intervening walls, rock mus somewhere in the house DANNY is listening to the Jefferson Airplane. The clink of teaspoon against china as LARRY stirs his te looks up at a noise: JUDY enters.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Honey.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (ABSENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Did you talk to Sy? Still absent, without looking up:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sy?-Sy Ableman!-That's right, he called, but I-

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You didn't talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, I-

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You know the problems you and I have been having. Sympathetic, but still absent:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Mm.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Well, Sy and I have become very close. This brings LARRY's head up. He focuses on JUDY, puzzled. elaborates: In.short: I think it's time to start talking about a divo LARRY stares at her. A long beat. At length, trying to digest:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . Sy Ableman!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: This is not about Sy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You mentioned Sy!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Don't twist my words. We-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A divorce-what have I done! I haven't done anything- What have I done!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: LARRY, don't be a child. You haven't "done" anything. I haven't "done" anything.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes! We haven't done anything! And I-I'm probably about to get tenure!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, there have been problems. As you know.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: And things have changed. And then-Sy Ableman. Sy has come into my life. And now-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Come into your-what does that mean?! You, you, you, you barely know him!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: We've known the Ablemans for fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes, but you you said we hadn't done anything! JUDY suddenly is stony:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: I haven't done anything. This is not some flashy fling. This is not about woopsy-doopsy. LARRY stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sy Ableman! From down the hall, a knock on a door. A muffled voice:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Out in a minute!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Look, I didn't know any other way of breaking it to you. Except to tell you. And treat you like an adult. Is that wrong? LARRY does not seem to be listening. His eyes roam the ro he thinks.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Where do I sleep? JUDY narrows her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur's on the couch!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Look. Sy feels that we should-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Esther is barely cold!

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: Esther died three years ago. And it was a loveless marriage. Sy wants a Gett. This derails the conversation. LARRY stares, trying to pi the thread.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . A what?

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: A ritual divorce. He says it's very important. Without a Gett I'm an Aguna.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A what? What are you talking about? She turns to go, shaking her head, peeved:

dialogues.speaker: JUDY
dialogues.text: You always act so surprised. As she leaves: I have begged you to see the Rabbi.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: LARRY has fallen asleep at the kitchen table, face-down i pile of blue books. Cold blue light sweeps across him and he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 A short, balding middle-aged man in flannel pyjamas and a flannel dressing gown stands in front of the open refrigerator holding an open of orange juice. He tips the jar back to drink, his free hand holding a balled-up towel to back of his neck LARRY stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: BLEGEN HALL
dialogues.text: LARRY enters the departmental office. His eyes are red-ri and dark-bagged. He has beard stubble. The department's secretary wheels her castored chair away her typing.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Messages, Professor Gopnik. He takes the two phone messages.

dialogues.speaker: HIS OFFICE
dialogues.text: LARRY looks at the messages: WHILE YOU WERE OUT Dick Dutton OF Columbia Record Club CALLED. REGARDING: "2Г‚В°d attempt. Please call." WHILE YOU WERE OUT Sy Ableman CALLED. REGARDING "Let's have a good talk." A knock brings his look up.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes-thanks for coming, CLIVE. CLIVE Park enters the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 . Have a seat. LARRY uses a key to open the top left desk drawer. He tak the envelope. We had, I think, a good talk, the other day, but you left something that-

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: I didn't leave it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well--you don't even know what I was going to say.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: I didn't leave anything. I'm not missing anything. I know where everything is. LARRY looks at him, trying to formulate a thought.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well... then, CLIVE, where did this come from? He waves the envelope. . This is here, isn't it? CLIVE looks at it gravely.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. That is there.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: This is not nothing, this is something.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Yes sir. That is something. A beat. . What is it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You know what it is! You know what it is! I believe. And

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 33 you know I can't keep it, CLIVE.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Of course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I'll have to pass it on to Professor Finkle, along with m suspicions about where it came from. Actions have consequences.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Yes. Often.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Always! Actions always have consequences! He pounds the desk for emphasis. In this office, actions have consequences!

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Not just physics. Morally.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And we both know about your actions.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: No sir. I know about my actions.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I can interpret, CLIVE. I know what you meant me to understand.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: Meer sir my sir. LARRY cocks his head.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . Meer sir my sir?

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: (careful enunciation) Mere... surmise. Sir. He gravely shakes his head. . Very uncertain.

dialogues.speaker: A TONE ARM
dialogues.text: A hand lays it onto a slowly spinning vinyl record. Through scratches and pops, a solo tenor starts a mournfu chant. Close on the sleeve: Rabbi Youssele Rosenblatt Chants Your Haftorah Portion

dialogues.speaker: VOLUME 12
dialogues.text: Rabbi Youssele wears a caftan and a felt hat and has sad They peer out from the dark beard that covers most of the rest of his face like eyes peering out of the woods. Wider, on DANNY, in his bedroom, evening. He lifts the to on the portable turntable. He chants the passage. He drops the tone arm at the same place; Rabbi Youssele c the passage again. DANNY listens, eyes narrowed. He lifts the tone arm and c the passage again. He replays the passage again; before he can lift the tone to echo it his door bursts open. Rabbi Youssele continues to chant.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You little brat fucker! You snuck twenty bucks out of my drawer!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Studying torah! Asshole!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: You little brat! I'm telling Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? You gonna tell him you've been sneaking it out of his wallet?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: All right, you know what I'm gonna do? You little brat? I you don't give it back? We hear the thunk of the front door opening. DANNY stands

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: FOYER
dialogues.text: LARRY is entering with his briefcase. As he stows it in t closet DANNY's voice continues, off:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad, you gotta fix the aerial. Judith emerges from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Hello LARRY, have you thought about a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Honey, please! DANNY emerges from the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 36 We're not getting channel four at all.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (to Judith) Can we discuss it later?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: I can't get F Troop.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: LARRY, the children know. Do you think this is some secre Do you think this is something we're going to keep quiet? SARAH enters.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Dad, Uncle Arthur is in the bathroom again! And I=m going to the hole at eight! She hits DANNY on the back of the head.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Stop it!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: SARAH! What's going on!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: She keeps doing that!

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: LARRY sits in a reclining chair in the living room, head listening to Sidor Belarsky on the hi-fi. On top of the music is a hissing-sucking sound is also the sound of a pencil busily scratching paper. We cut to its source: Uncle Arthur sits scribbling into a notebook, his free hand holding the end of a length of surgical tubing against th of his neck. The tube leads to a water-pik-like appliance on an end table next to him source of the sucking sound. After a long beat of listening to the music, LARRY speaks space:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur? Uncle Arthur does not look up from his scribbling. Uncle Arthur Yes. LARRY continues to stare at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What're you doing? Still without looking up: Uncle Arthur Working on the Mentaculus. Long beat. Music. Scribbling.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Any luck, um, looking for an apartment? More scribbling. Uncle Arthur No. The doorbell chimes.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DOOR
dialogues.text: LARRY enters, glances through the front door's head-heigh and-freezes, one hand arrested on the way to the doorknob. His point-of-view: framed by the window, yellowly lit by stoop light, a human head. A middle-aged man, a few years older than LARRY. A fleshy with droopy hangdog features, a five-o'clock shadow, and sad Harold Bloom eye LARRY opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Sy. Sy, entering, thrusts out a hand. His voice vibrates with sad empathy:

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Good to see you, LARRY. He is a heavy-set man wearing a short-sleeved shirt that belly tents out in front of him. In his left hand he holds a bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (TIGHTLY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get Judith.

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: No, actually LARRY, I'm here to see you, if I might. He shakes his head. . Such a thing. Such a thing.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Shall we go in the... He is leading him into the kitchen but Sy, oblivious to s plows on with the conversation, arresting both men in the narrow space betw kitchen sink and stove, and invading LARRY's space.

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: You know, LARRY-how we handle ourselves, in this situation-it's so impawtant.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Judith told me that she broke the news to you She said you were very adult.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Did she.

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. The respect she has for you.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Absolutely. But the children, LARRY. The children. He shakes his head. . The most impawtant.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Of coss. And Judith says they're handling it so well. A tribute to you. Do you drink wine? Because this is an incredible bottle. This is not Mogen David. This is a win LARRY. A bawdeaux.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: You know, Sy-

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: Open it-let it breathe. Ten minutes. Letting it breathe, impawtant.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sy, but I'm not-

dialogues.speaker: SY
dialogues.text: I insist! No reason for discumfit. I'll be uncumftable if you don't take it. These are signs and tokens, LARRY.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I'm just-I'm not ungrateful, I'm, I just don't know a lot about wine and, given our respective, you know- He is startled when Sy abruptly hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 40 S' okay. He finishes the hug off with a couple of thumps on the ba S'okay. Wuhgonnabe fine.

dialogues.speaker: PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: We are dutch on a slit of a view through a cracked-open f window: the Hebrew school parking lot. The last couple of busses filled with students are rollin of the lot. It is late afternoon. A reverse shows DANNY in a stall, standing on a closed to angling his head to peer out the bathroom window opened at the top. The bathroom outside the stall: Ronnie Nudell leans again sink waiting, sucking a long draw from a joint. DANNY emerges from the stall. Ronnie Nudell offers the jo Ronnie Nudell Want some of this fucker?

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The bathroom door cracks open in the foreground. DANNY pe out. His point-of-view: the empty hallway ending in a T with a hallway. A janitor crosses, pushing a broom down the far hallway. He disappe His echoing footsteps recede. DANNY and Ronny emerge from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI MINDA
dialogues.text: The photo-portrait on the wall of Mar Turchik's office li late-day sun. We hear a scraping sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 Wider: Ronnie Nudell looks over DANNY's shoulder as DANNY at Mar Turchik's desk, fishes the end of a bent hanger into the keyhole on top left drawer. After a beat, the hanger turns. They open the drawer. In it: squirt guns, marbles set to by the opening of the drawer, a comic book, a Playboy magazine, a slingshot, a bundle of firecrackers. Hands rifle the gewgaws: no radio. Ronnie Nudell Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: SANCTUARY
dialogues.text: We are behind the two boys who sit side by side on the la staring at the front of the empty sanctuary. Its stained glass windows further we the late-afternoon light. In deference to the location, the boys wear yarmulkas. A long hold on their still backs. At length, some movement in DANNY's back, his head dips, we hear him sucking on the joint. He holds it, exhales, and passes it wordlessly Ronnie Nudell.

dialogues.speaker: SUBURBAN STREET
dialogues.text: We are pulling DANNY as he walks along the street, eyes r still wearing his yarmulka. It is dusk. After a few beats of walking, the front door of a house j behind DANNY opens. A husky, shaggy-haired youth emerges on the run. The sound has alerted DANNY. Seeing Mike Fagle, he too be to run. He reaches up and grabs his yarmulka and clutches it in one of his pump fists. Pursued and pursuer both run wordlessly, panting, feet po Mike Fagle is closing. But DANNY is already cutting acros Brandt's front yard, approaching his own. He plunges into the house and slams door. Mike Fagle draws up, panting, gazing hungrily at the hous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42 Lights are on inside. The house is a warm yellow citadel dusk. After a beat we hear, faint and dulled, the Jefferson Air Mike Fagle slinks away.

dialogues.speaker: PUFFY WHITE CLOUDS
dialogues.text: A shockingly blue sky with picture-perfect clouds hanging it. After a beat the top of an aluminum extension ladder swin from the bottom of the frame and comes toward us. We cut to a side angle as the ladder clunk against a roof It starts vibrating to the rhythmic clung of someone clim Hands enter. LARRY's head enters. He climbs onto the roof. He takes a couple steps away from the edge and stands ten making sure of his balance. He looks around. His point-of-view towards the front. An unfamiliarly high on the street and the neighboring houses, almost maplike. Very peaceful. Wi gently waves the trees. LARRY gingerly walks up to the aerial at the peak of the We are hearing a rhythmic popping noise. LARRY reaches the peak and straddles it. He looks down at back yard.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ow. Foreshortened Gar Brandt and Mitch are playing catch in t back yard. With each toss the ball pops, alternately in father's mitt and son's. Precariously balanced, LARRY reaches out for the aerial. touches it. He grasps it. He twists the aerial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 43 Something strange: as it rotates the aerial creaks-a high as pure as the hum sounded from the rim of a wineglass.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ow. Faintly, under the wineglass sound, and clouded by static high, ringing tenor sings in an unfamiliar modality. Cantorial music. LARRY drops his hand. Inertia keeps the aerial rotating s til it dies, the sound drifting away into the sybillant shushing of trees. LARRY reaches out again to turn the aerial. The same crys hum... cantorial singing... and now, layering in, the theme from F Troop. Music. Crystal hum. Wind.

dialogues.speaker: MITCH
dialogues.text: Ow. LARRY's look travels: his point-of-view pans slowly off t angle of father and son playing catch, travels across his own backyard, and bring the white fence that encloses the patio of the neighbor on the other side. Gar (off) Good toss, Mitch. On the enclosed patio a woman reclines on a lawn chaise o bands woven over an aluminum frame. She is on her back, eyes closed against t She is naked. Mitch (off) Ow. LARRY reacts to the naked woman: startled at first, he mo to hide behind the peak of the roof. But as he realizes that the sun keeps the woman's e closed he relaxes, continu- ing to stare. She is attractive. Not young, not old: LARRY's age. Peace After a still beat one of her hands gropes blindly to the It finds an ashtray on the table next to her and takes from it a pluming cigarette. woman takes a puff and replaces it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 Mitch (off) Ow. F Troop. Cantorial singing. Blue sky and white puffy clouds. The sound of a pencil scratching against paper.

dialogues.speaker: NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: A pencil scratches equations into a lamplit spiral notebo Sidor Belarsky comes in at the cut. So does the splutteri of Uncle Arthur's evacuator. Wider on Uncle Arthur, in his pyjamas, propped up on the fold-out sofa, writing with one hand as he holds the evacuator hose to his neck the other. Squeezed into the living room next to the fold-out sofa i camp cot of plaid-patterned nylon stretched over an aluminum frame. On the camp cot i lying half-in, half- out of a rumpled sleeping bag. He stares at the ceiling, washcloth pressed against his forehead. His face is flaming red. Arthur speaks absently as he scribbles:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Will you read this? Tell me what you think? LARRY continues to stare at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Uncle Arthur glances up from the notebook, focuses on LAR

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Boy. You should've worn a hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45 The lights are out. Very quiet. Uncle Arthur lightly snor LARRY still stares at the ceiling. He shifts his weight. aluminum frame of the cot squeaks. He shifts again. Another creak. LARRY fishes his watch from the jumble of clothes on the 4:50.

dialogues.speaker: KITCHEN
dialogues.text: LARRY, in his underwear, spoons ground coffee into the pe Uncle Arthur snores softly on in the other room. From outside, a dull thunk. LARRY pulls back a curtain. Next door, Gar Brandt is going down the walk, wearing cam togs and camo billed cap, a rifle bag slung over his shoulder. He is carrying chest, its contents clicking and sloshing. The boy Mitch, also wearing camo clothes and cap and also a rifle bag, has just closed the front door. He now lets the screen door swing behind him and follows his father down the walk to the car in the driveway. The twitter of early morning birds. Gar's voice, though n stands out in the pre-dawn quiet:

dialogues.speaker: GAR
dialogues.text: Let's see some hustle, Mitch.

dialogues.speaker: THE NOTEBOOK
dialogues.text: Its top sheet, densely covered by equations, has a headin The Mentaculus Compiled by Arthur Gopnik After a beat LARRY's hand enters to turn the page. The se page is also densely covered with equations.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: This brings LARRY's look up from the Mentaculus. We are i office. Standing in the office doorway is Arlen Finkle.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Hi Arlen. Arlen Finkle LARRY, I feel that, as head of the tenure committee I sho tell you this, though it should be no cause for concern. should not be at all worried. LARRY waits for more. Arlen seems to need a prompt.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Arlen Finkle I feel I should mention it even though we won't give this any weight at all in considering whether to grant you tenure, so, I repeat no cause for concern.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, Arlen. Give what any weight? Arlen Finkle We have received some letters, uh... denigrating you, and well, urging that we not grant you tenure.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY

dialogues.text: I'm going to the hole. DANNY enters the kitchen and sits at the setting across f his sister. He picks up his spoon. Some movement in SARAH's body; DANNY recoils from a kick.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Ow! Cut it out!

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: What's going on? The siblings slurp soup, neither answering. After a couple slurps: . Isn't Dad eating?

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: He's at the Jolly Roger.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. More eating.

dialogues.speaker: SIEGLESTEIN, SCHLUTZ
dialogues.text: In a small windowless conference room lined by bookshelve with law reference books, LARRY rises to greet Don Milgram, entering.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Don.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: How are you, LARRY, Jesus, I am so sorry to be seeing you under these circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, well...

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I always thought you and JUDY were rock solid. This is so terrible, LARRY. This is devastating.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well, the way I look at it, it's an opportunity for me to really sit down and figure things out, and, and, look at world afresh instead of just, you know, settling for the routine, tired old way of looking at things. Don Milgram stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: . Really?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (DEFLATING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe not.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Well, legally, I have to warn you, it's never easy for th husband. Unless, of course, there's some question of the wife having violated the marriage contract.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh no, nothing like that. She's planning to marry Sy Ableman, but they-

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Sy Ableman!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes, but they-

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Esther is barely cold!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: She passed three years ago.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Well, okay, still-this changes the complexion, LARRY! Sy Ableman!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Not in the sense that... there hasn't been hanky-panky. T my knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No. I'm fairly certain this is not an issue. And in fact uh, Judith wants a Gett. Beat. Don stares blankly at LARRY. LARRY clears his throat. A ritual divorce.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So that they can remarry in the faith-

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, sure, not really a legal matter. Okay. Well. My goodness. How are the children taking it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh, they're very... He gropes. . resilient.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Good. Well. On the other thing, the neighbor's property line, I've asked Solomon Schlutz to take a look. There's very little having to do with real estate that'll get by

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay. Good. How do you-I guess I'm a little worried, how do you, I have money pressures and-

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Our fee structure? We bill by the hour. Dave Sieglestein and Solomon Schlutz bill at a hundred and ten, the associ ates, me for instance, bill at A secretary sticks her head in.

dialogues.text: A call for Mr. Gopnik. DANNY. At home.

dialogues.text: You can take it here.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Oh-eight-oh-nine. LARRY punches a button on a row of four on the conference telephone.

dialogues.text: Are you all right? Are you all-is everything-

dialogues.text: . What?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAWN AT THE JOLLY ROGER
dialogues.text: Wide on the motel room, dimly lit by weak sun starting to in around the curtain. LARRY sleeps in one of the twin beds; Uncle Arthur snores the other. Uncle Arthur's breath snags and tangles on a snorfling in and it wakes him, gagging. He blinks, sits up, swings his legs out, gazes blearily a the room. He rises stiffly and heads for the bathroom. LARRY stirs. The sound of Uncle Arthur urinating. LARRY l blearily around. LARRY stiffly rises. He takes the two steps across the ro the formica desk on which are spread papers for his class. As we hear the sucking s of the neck evacuator in the bathroom, LARRY sweeps papers together and mechanical his briefcase.

dialogues.text: LARRY is driving, hollow-eyed, to work. After a long beat of staring, the ka-ching of a bicycle b

dialogues.text: 75 LARRY's eyes widen and his head swivels, tracking as he o and passes: The bicyclist. A young Asian man wearing a white traffic- LARRY looks at him in the rear-view.

dialogues.speaker: CLIVE
dialogues.text: He starts frantically pumping down his window, shouting: . CLIVE! You gonna send your mother next?! You little bastard! I wanna see you! I wanna- Crash. He has rear-ended someone. A blaring horn, a quick second crash: wrenching steel and glass. He has been rear-ended in turn. The ka-ching of the bicycle. CLIVE Park cycles past witho

dialogues.text: LARRY enters the outer office, hugging his paper-stuffed to his chest. The secretary is just crooking the phone into her shoulde

dialogues.text: (BLANK)

dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Gopnik, this is Dick Dutton from the Columbia Record Club. I'm calling because it is now, what, four months and we have yet to receive your first payment.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I-there's some mistake. I'm not a member of the Columbian Record Club.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Sir, you are Lawrence Gopnik of 1425 Flag Avenue South?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, I live at the Jolly Roger.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, I-well, yes, okay.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes you are Lawrence Gopnik?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay means...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, yes, Lawrence Gopnik, yes.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay, well, you received your twelve introductory albums and you have been receiving the monthly main selection fo four months now-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: "The monthly main selection?" Is that a record? I didn't

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 77 ask for any records.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: To receive the monthly main selection you do nothing.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: That's right! I haven't done anything!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Yes, that's why you receive the monthly main selection. The last

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: But I-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: The last one was Santana Abraxis. You-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I didn't ask for Santana Abraxis!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: You request the main selection at the retail price by doi nothing. It is automatically mailed to you. Plus shipping and handling. You're about to-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I can't afford a new record every month! I haven't asked

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: You're about to get Cosmo's Factory, sir. The June main selection. And you haven't-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Look, something is very wrong! I don't want Santana Abraxis! I've just been in a terrible auto accident! Beat.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry sir.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well-thank you. But I-

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, no one was hurt.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Okay. Good. Well, you had fourteen days to listen to Santana Abraxis and return it if you weren't completely satisfied. You did nothing. And now you-

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I didn't ask for Santana Abraxis! I didn't listen to Sant Abraxis! I didn't do anything! The secretary is sticking her head in.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Sir. Please. We can't make you listen to the record. We-

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Professor Gopnik, your son. He said it's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay, look, I have to call you back, this is, this is I'm sorry. He irritably punches a button on the bottom row of four.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Did you join the Columbia Record Club?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 79 Silence.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Um...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: DANNY, this is completely unacceptable. I can't afford to

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Okay Dad, but you gotta come home.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Is it F Troop?

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Huh? No no. Mom's real upset.

dialogues.speaker: GOPNIK HOUSE
dialogues.text: LARRY enters. We can hear weeping, semi-hysterical, from in the house. SARAH's Voice .Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes? She enters.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Does this mean I can't go to the hole tonight?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Does what mean-what happened?

dialogues.speaker: SARAH
dialogues.text: Sy Ableman died in a car crash. DANNY's Voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 Hey Dad!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What?! DANNY enters.

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: So are you coming back home? Can you fix the aerial? The weeping, off, grows louder and more hysterical.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: It's still, you know... Loud wailing.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK
dialogues.text: After a beat in black, a white title: The Second Rabbi The title fades.

dialogues.speaker: RABBI'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: We are close on LARRY. He sits hunched forward, hands cla in front of him, staring at the floor, sadly shaking his head. After a long beat:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It seems like she's asking an awful lot. But then-I don't know. Somebody has to pay for Sy's funeral. Rabbi Nachtner, sitting opposite, nods. Rabbi Nachtner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: His own estate is in probate. But why does it have to be me? Or is it wrong to complain? JUDY says it is. But I'm so strapped for cash right now-paying for the Jolly Roger and I wrecked the car, and DANNY's bar mitzvah... I... Rabbi Nachtner Something like this-there's never a good time.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don't know where it all leaves me. Sy's death. Obviousl it's not going to go back like it was. Rabbi Nachtner Mm. Would you even want that, LARRY?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No, I-well yeah! Sometimes! Or-I don't know; I guess the honest answer is I don't know. What was my life before? Not what I thought it was. What does it all mean? What is Hashem trying to tell me, making me pay for Sy Ableman's funeral? Rabbi Nachtner Mm.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And-did I tell you I had a car accident the same time Sy had his? The same instant, for all I know. Is Hashem telling me that Sy Ableman is me, or we are all one or something? Rabbi Nachtner How does God speak to us: it's a good question. You know Lee Sussman?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: DOCTOR Sussman? I think I-yeah. Rabbi Nachtner Did he ever tell you about the goy's teeth?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No... I-What goy? Rabbi Nachtner So Lee is at work one day; you know he has the orthodonti practice there at Texa-Tonka.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Rabbi Nachtner Right next to the Gold Eagle Cleaners. We cut to:

dialogues.speaker: SIGN FOR THE GOLD EAGLE CLEANERS
dialogues.text: It dominates a small suburban strip mall. Rabbi Nachtner continues in voice-over as we cut to a smo glass door that identifies Leon Sussman, DDS. Rabbi Nachtner He's making a plaster mold-it's for corrective bridge work-in the mouth of one of his patients... A close shot of a man's mouth biting down on two horse-sh troughs-an upper and a lower-that overflow an oozing white goo. . Russell Kraus. He's a delivery dispatcher for the Star and Tribune with chronic mandicular deterioration. The grinding guitar solo from Jefferson Airplane's "Bear scores the narrative. The patient opens his mouth as a hand enters to grab the tray. The reverse shows Dr. Sussman, a balding middle-aged man, in the the high- collared white smock of an oral surgeon. He carries the m over to a drying table. Kraus is twisted over the side of the chair spitting into water-swirled spit-sink. . Well, the mold dries and Lee is examining it one day

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 before fabricating an appliance... Another day: Dr. Sussman is sitting at his desk examining lower mold. He notices something unusual. . He notices something unusual. Sussman reaches up for the loupe attached to his eyeglass There seems to be something engraved on the inside of the patient's lower incisors... He flips down the loupe. His eyes are hugely magnified as stares. Sure enough, it's writing. Sussman squints. His point-of-view: Tiny incised Hebrew letters: smlГЇВїВЅnn

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO RABBI NACHTNER
dialogues.text: He confirms with a nod. Rabbi Nachtner This in a goy's mouth, LARRY.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO LEON SUSSMAN
dialogues.text: The Rabbi's narrative continues. Rabbi Nachtner Tet resh nun lamed nun shin tsayin. What is that-tiranu linoshets? "Help me"? Is that what it says? Or is it a name? It's not Kraus's name. Sussman flips the loupe away and looks off, haunted. He r He checks the mold, just to be sure. Oh, it's there all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 84 right... A dental mirror is dipped into the horse-shoe-shaped hard paste of the mold. It pans tiny letters that stand out in relief, right-side around mirror: yw .rin Sussman leans back, thinking. He calls the goy back on the pretense of needing addition measurements for the appliance... Close on Kraus grinning as he shakes Sussman's hand in th area. Sussman gestures to invite Kraus back to the examination room. Sussman chats, affecting nonchalance. In the examination room, leaning over Kraus in the chair, dentist is indeed chatting with seeming casualness. Notice any other problems with your teeth? Anything peculiar, et cetera? Sussman takes a dental mirror. No. No. No. Visited any other dentist recently? He looks in Kraus' mouth with the mirror: Ym nn Sussman frowns. There it is. "Help me"? He leans back. Sussman goes home. Can Sussman eat? No. Sussman sits at the kitchen table, untouched food in fron him. His wife chats volubly while Sussman stares into space. Can Sussman sleep? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 85 Sussman is in bed, pyjamas buttoned to the neck, staring ceiling. What does it mean? Is it a message for him, for Sussman? And if so, from whom? Does Sussman know? Sussman doesn't know. Back in the dental office Sussman pulls boxes containing molds off the shelf. Sussman looks at the molds of his other patients, goy and Jew alike, seeking other messages. He finds none. He looks in his own mouth... Close on Sussman in front of a mirror straining to see th of a reflection of the dental mirror he holds in his own mouth. . Nothing. His wife's mouth... Sussman's wife lies asleep on her back, her mouth open, s softly. Sussman, in pyjamas but with his glasses on and loupe in place, lies her in bed, supporting himself with one arm thrown across her body. He leans awk in, carefully lowering a dental mirror into his wife's open mouth. . Nothing. It is a singular event. A mystery. The Jefferson Airplane guitar solo is heating up. But Sussman is an educated man. Not the world's greatest sage, maybe, no Rabbi Minda, but he knows a thing or two from the Zohar and the Caballah. He knows every Hebrew letter has its numeric equivalent. Sussman, still in his pyjamas is sitting at the kitchen t scribbling on a tablet of lined paper. Close on the paper: the Hebrew letters have been transcri into their numeric

dialogues.speaker: EQUIVALENTS
dialogues.text: 496-2428 Nachtner continues in voice-over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 Seven digits-a phone number maybe? Sussman reaches for the phone. He hesitates a moment, the . Sussman dials. It rings.

dialogues.speaker: AN ELEVATED CUBICLE
dialogues.text: In a grocery store. A man in short sleeves reaches for th Rabbi Nachtner It's a Red Owl grocery store in Bloomington. Hello? Do you know a goy named Kraus? Russel Kraus? The store manager is shaking his head. Where have I called? The Red Owl. In Bloomington. Thanks so much. The manager, puzzled, hangs up. Sussman thinks, am I supposed to go to the Red Owl, to receive a further sign? He goes... In the parking lot of the Red Owl Sussman, wearing a shor fedora, emerges from his car. It is an unremarkable grocery store in a su mall. It's a Red Owl. Inside Sussman, in his fedora, gazes around. Groceries. What have you. A service alley behind the store: dumpsters, wind-blown g Sussman looking. On the wall behind the store, a stain... There is an old, rather nondescript stain of some liquid against the back wall and long since dribbled away. . Could be a nun sofit... Or maybe not... The parking lot again: Sussman gets back in his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 87 Sussman goes home. What does it mean? He has to find out, if he's ever to sleep again. Sussman again, in pyjamas buttoned to the neck, lies in h staring at the ceiling. He goes to see the Rabbi, Nachtner. He comes in and sits right where you're sitting now. Sussman is indeed sitting across from Rabbi Nachtner, jus we've seen LARRY sitting. What does it mean, Rabbi? Is it a sign from Hashem? "Help me." I, Sussman, should be doing something to help this goy? Doing what? The teeth don't say. I should know without asking? Or maybe I'm supposed to help people generally-lead a more righteous life? Is the answer in cabalah? In torah? Or is there even a question? Tell me, Rabbi-what can such a sign mean? Nachtner-not the narrating Nachtner but the Nachtner in t and considers.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Staring at the Rabbi. He waits a good beat. He prompts:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: So what did you tell him? The Rabbi seems surprised by the question. Rabbi Nachtner Sussman?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes! Rabbi Nachtner Is it. . relevant?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Well-isn't that why you're telling me? Rabbi Nachtner Mm. Okay. Nachtner says, look.. . We are back in the scene, narrated by voice-over, of the silently advising the fretful Sussman. . The teeth, we don't know. A sign from Hashem, don't know. Helping others, couldn't hurt. LARRY's voice-over question plays over Sussman asking the thing: LARRY (of]) But is that what it meant?-tet resh nun lamed nun shin isayin, was it "Help me"? or a number? Or was it Rabbi Nachtner (off) We can't know everything. Sussman stares blankly at the Rabbi. A beat. LARRY (of]) It sounds like you don't know Mthing!

dialogues.speaker: THE RABBI
dialogues.text: Smiling equably at LARRY. He reacts to the ejaculation wi shrug. LARRY scowls.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Why even tell me the story? Rabbi Nachtner (AMUSED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First I should tell you, then I shouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 89 LARRY, exasporated, changes tack:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: What happened to Sussman?

dialogues.speaker: SUSSMAN
dialogues.text: In his office. Working on different patients as the Rabbi his voice-over. Rabbi Nachtner What would happen? Not much. He went back to work. For a while he checked every patient's teeth for new messages; didn't see any; in time, he found he'd stopped checking. Sussman, at home, chats with his wife over dinner. . These questions that are bothering you, LARRY-maybe they're like a toothache. We feel them for a while, then they go away. Sussman lies in bed sleeping, smiling, an arm thrown acro wife.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Dissatisfied.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I don't want it to just go away! I want an answer! Rabbi Nachtner The answer! Sure! We all want the answer! But Hashem doesn't owe us the answer, LARRY. Hashem doesn't owe us anything. The obligation runs the other way.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Why does he make us feel the questions if he's not gonna give us any answers? Rabbi Nachtner smiles at LARRY for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 Rabbi Nachtner He hasn't told me. LARRY rubs his face, frustrated. A last question occurs to him:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: And what happened to the goy? Rabbi Nachtner's forebearing smile fades into puzzlement. Rabbi Nachtner The goy? Who cares?

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: The modern synagogue grafted onto a patch of prairie. An echoing voice rings out:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Sy Ableman was a serious man!

dialogues.speaker: RABBI NACHTNER
dialogues.text: In close-up he gazes around, weighing the effect of the w just delivered. After a long beat during which he seeks to establish eye with as much of his audience as possible: Rabbi Nachtner . Sy Ableman was a man devoted to his community... Wider shows Rabbi Nachtner up on the bema. He and the con face each other across a casket down at floor level. . to torah study... LARRY sits among the congregants, his gaze fixed on a poi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 91 . to his beloved wife Esther until, three years ago, she passed.. . LARRY's point-of-view: JUDY is visible from 3 behind. She a few rows ahead looking grimly up at the rabbi. . and to his duty, as he saw it. Where does such a man go? A tzadik-who knows, maybe even a lamid vovnik-a man beloved by all, a man who despised the frivolous? Could such a serious man... simply... disappear? The words echo. Again the rabbi gazes around, as if awaiting answer.

dialogues.speaker: THEN
dialogues.text: . We speak of L'olam ha-ba, the World to Come. Not heaven. Not what the gentiles think of as afterlife. "L'olam ha-ba." What is L'olam ha-ba? Where is L'olam ha-ba? Well: it is not a geoaraphic place, certainly. Like-Canada. Murmured chuckles from the congregation. Nor is it the eretz zavat chalav ood'vash-the land flowin with milk and honey, for we are not promised a personal reward, a gold star, a first-class VIP lounge where we ge milk and cookies to eternity! More chuckles. L'olam ha-ba... is in the bosom of Abraham. L'olam ba- ba is in the soul of this community which nurtured Sy Ableman and to which Sy Ableman now returns. That's right, he returns. Because he still inspires us Ableman returns. Because his memory instructs us Ableman returns. Because his thoughts illuminate our days and way Sy Ableman returns. The frivolous man may vanish without a ripple but Sy Ableman? Sy Ableman was a serious man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92 A sob echoes through the sanctuary. LARRY looks at Judith, who stifles further sobs with a ha . As you know, the mourner's kaddish does not mention the dead. It praises Hashem; it praises what abides. And Sy Ableman, whose spirit will continue to assist us in tikkun olam, is with us even now, a serious man who would say as we now say Yiskadal v'yiskadash sh'may rabah... The congregation begins to chant along but it and Judith' are cut off by:

dialogues.speaker: A HAND RAPPING AT A DOOR
dialogues.text: The front door to the Gopnik home. LARRY, still in his suit from shul and wearing a yarmulka the door. He recoils in surprise edged with fear. Reverse: two uniformed policemen.

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: Arthur Gopnik? LARRY is momentarily dumb. Inside the house we can see a of a card table set up in the living room with food laid out on it. SARAH sits with back to us, head wrapped by a towel-turban. Arthur, on the far side of the table, his head domed by a yarmul- ka, half-leans out so that he may sneak looks toward the at the door without totally revealing himself. From somewhere down the hall come Judi muffled sobs. . Are you Arthur Gopnik?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I'm... Laurence Gopnik. Cop I Do you go by the name Arthur Gopnik?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: Is that Arthur Gopnik? Arthur ducks away. From inside the living room: DANNY (off) Dad? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Can you tell me what's going on. We're sitting shiva here

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: You're what.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: A religious observance. We're... bereaved. The cop standing behind gazes in over his partner's shoul

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: Who died?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
