Just tel him I need help. Please. I need help. He lapses into silence, staring at the secretary. She stares inscrutably back. After a moment she rises, goes to the door behind her, op it, shuffles into the dimness of an inner office. LARRY cranes to see past her. Her own body and the dimnes with a good view of the figure hunched behind the desk. The man is old and His desktop is empty. Murmured voices in Hebrew. A clock ticks in the outer office. LARRY looks around, wa Mysterious Judaica adorns the outer office. The old woman is shuffling back. She closes the door on t rabbi and sits down, heavily, behind her own desk.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: The rabbi is busy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: He didn't look busy! As she starts shuffling papers:

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: He's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Sidor Belarsky comes in at the cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 119 We are booming down on LARRY, asleep in bed. We hear weeping, soft, suppressed. LARRY stirs. He opens his eyes. After a groggy beat he reacts to the weeping. He looks ov

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur... ? Arthur? Arthur is a dim mound on the next bed. His weeping contin For no reason LARRY continues to keep his voice to a whis . Arthur. What's wrong? No answer. . Arthur. It'll be okay. Arthur. We'll get Ron Meshbesher. It'll be okay-

dialogues.speaker: AAAHHHH
dialogues.text: Shockingy loud, the scream is hard to interpret. Arthur flings off his bedclothes. He leaps from the bed a to the door. In boxer shorts and undershirt he flings the door open and runs ou the room.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur! LARRY leaps from his bed, also in his underwear. He goes to the door but pauses, peering cautiously outsid that the courtyard is deserted, he plunges into it.

dialogues.speaker: COURTYARD
dialogues.text: The courtyard/parking lot is hardlit by ghastly mercury v lights. The pool, surrounded by chain-link fence, has been drained. Its whi interior is cracked

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120 and weedy. Uncle Arthur is hunched weeping in a corner of the pool e

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: (HISSING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! He opens the creaking gate and scurries over to Arthur. . You've got to pull yourself together! Arthur is suddenly angry. His voice bounces off the concr

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It's all shit, LARRY! It's all shit!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur. Don't use that word.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: It's all fucking shit!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur! Come on!

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Look at everything Hashem has given you! And what do I get! I get fucking shit!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur. What do I have. I live at the Jolly Roger.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: You've got a family. You've got a job. Hashem hasn't given me bupkes.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's not fair to blame Hashem, Arthur. Please. Sometimes -please calm down-sometimes you have to help your- self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 121 Don't blame me! You fucker!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur. Please.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Hashem hasn't given me shit. Now I can't even play cards. He starts weeping again. LARRY looks around.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur. This isn't the right forum. Please. Not by the pool. Arthur weeps. Arthur... It's okay... It's okay...

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: LARRY and Arthur are driving. We are looking at the two o square through a windshield in which towering conifers stream by in reflec It seems to be a glorious day.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Is this it? Both men peer out.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I think so... yeah... there... He indicates the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: A SIGNPOST
dialogues.text: The old-fashioned kind with wooden fingers pointing the d directions. One points toward CANADA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 122 We tip off the sign as LARRY's car passes and recedes. Th is a canoe strapped to its roof.

dialogues.speaker: BOUNDARY WATERS
dialogues.text: Beautiful, wooded, remote. The car is parked at water's edge, having backed down a l of two tracks worn through the undergrowth. LARRY and Arthur are lowering th into water.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Okay.. . He straightens. Arthur straightens. LARRY hugs him. .Look... They separate and LARRY pulls a white envelope from his p and gives it to Arthur. . This'll help you get back on your feet. Arthur looks into the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Oh my God. Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. When you-

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: This is a lot of money!

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It should get you started.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: This is a lot of money! Are you sure you don't need it?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Arthur, I'm fine. Come on, get in. When you're settled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 123 Arthur climbs into the canoe. . let me know how to get in touch. He helps push the boat off. Arthur is twisted around, loo back. As he drifts off:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is okay?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's fine. It's fine... LARRY waves. Arthur waves bravely back, then turns to pick up the oars couple of strokes and he turns back again with a last thought. He calls:

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: LARRY. I'm sorry. What I said last night.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I know. It's okay. A lingering look from Arthur, and then he turns back to r A gunshot. Blood spurts from the back of Uncle Arthur's neck. He slumps forward, dead.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Good shot! LARRY looks wildly around. He sees: Gar Brandt and Mitch in their camo fatigues, hard to pick in the foliage. They are looking off toward the canoe, Mitch just lowering his rif Gar Brandt's look swings around, into the lens. He points us: There's another Jew, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 124 Mitch swings his rifle toward us. He fires.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Gasping awake in the motel room. He looks around. It is dawn. Arthur sits on the edge of his bed in his underwear, star off into space, slackjawed, vacant-eyed, drained. LARRY gazes around the room, waiting for things to fall i place. Finally, blearily:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Were we... out at the pool last night? Arthur, still staring off, responds in a flat, empty voic

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm sorry. LARRY blinks sleep away. After a beat:

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's shabbas. Another beat. Arthur heaves a deep sigh.

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR
dialogues.text: I'll go drain my cyst.

dialogues.speaker: RESTROOM
dialogues.text: Day. A two-urinal, two-stall men's room of old tile and y fixtures. We are low. One of the stall doors is closed. Under it we the dress shoes and dress pants of two young men standing inside. We hear a long sucking inhale. Ronnie Nudell's Voice Gimme that fucker. A loudly projected echoing male voice:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Ya'amod hab'rayshit.

dialogues.speaker: SANCTUARY
dialogues.text: DANNY, seated in the second pew next to his parents and s and Uncle Arthur, rises and shuffles along the row to the aisle. His eyes are wid red-rimmed. The prelapped voice was his call to the torah. All eyes i congregation, which fills the large sanctuary, are on him. In great echoing silence he walks to the steps on the rig of the bema and climbs. The right-side lectern is surrounded by a gaggle of old J men. They busy themselves with the preparation of the pair of scrolls on lectern, rolling them, pausing, rolling some more, muttering prayers, kissing th by means of their tsitsim. They pay DANNY no attention. DANNY takes his place centered behind the lectern. His ch up to the bottom of the reading platform. Men continue to mutter prayers around him. A pair of hand on his shoulders from behind. DANNY looks down at the strange hands. They him back. A foot drags a small riser out from under the lectern. Hands push DANNY up onto the riser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 126 Booming up on the torah scrolls, still being busily rolle Beyond it, a sea of faces. The yad-a molded tin pointer-is thrust into DANNY's hand. non-pointing end has a red silken tassel. DANNY looks at the bouncing tassel. He looks at the littl finger which is the business end of the yad. Men mutter around him, each a different prayer. They dip doven. DANNY watches himself point the yad down at the scroll. The scroll is a dense swarm of Hebrew letters. DANNY squi One voice separates from the murmurs around him. It chant in a sotto-voce

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Nefesh echad sheichayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot... DANNY is still staring at the end of the yad against the scroll. Someone's hand enters and moves the yad to a different pl in the text. The voice repeats: . Nefesh echad sheichayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot... DANNY looks up from the scrolls. In the congregation Ronnie Nudell sits hunched-shouldered squished between his parents. He returns DANNY's red-rimmed slack-jawed stare. The insistent voice: . Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot... DANNY looks over. From the surrounding scrum the prompter nods at him. He l somewhat like Cantor Youssele Rosenblatt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 . Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot.. . DANNY looks back down at the scroll. A hand enters to tap finger where the yad points. . Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effa- DANNY suddenly erupts:

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Nefesh echad shelchayim, yitzeh gamor shel effashot. .

dialogues.speaker: PROMPTER
dialogues.text: Mm-hm. DANNY continues to boom out the torah portion. He moves t along the line of letters. In the congregation, LARRY and Judith watch. We hear DANN fluently and LARRY squeezes the hand Judith has laced through his arm. Juith whispers:

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: I'm sorry that... things have been so hard for us...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: JUDITH
dialogues.text: Sy had so much respect for you, LARRY. He pats her hand. A beat. . He wrote letters to the tenure committee.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: The congregation is loudly singing V'Zos Hatorah. A talli man of late middle age

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 128 hoists the open scroll from the lectern and raises it hig his back on the congregation so that all may see it. DANNY has been ensconced in a highbacked chair upstage on bema. His point-of-view of the man holding the torah is close a raked. The man is sweating. The heavy scrolls vibrate slightly from his eff to keep them aloft. As the congregation continues to sing he mutters under his breat

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ.. .

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: DANNY stands behind the left lectern facing Rabbi Nachtne holds a small kiddush cup out to him. Although Rabbi Nachtner seems to be addressing DANNY, he loudly.

dialogues.speaker: NACHTNER
dialogues.text: . taking your place as a member of our tribe. You will go and see Rabbi Minda after the service. You will cele- brate in a reception downstairs in Schanfield Hall. And then you will be a member of B'Nai Abraham and of the Nation of Israel. DANNY Gopnik, the Sisterhood makes a gift to you of this kiddush cup so that you will remember this blessed day on the next shabbas and the next, and on every shabbas of a long and fruitful life, and, until tha wonderful day when you stand under the chupa, we say.. .

dialogues.speaker: CONGREGATION
dialogues.text: Amen. DANNY, still red-eyed, tries to focus. His point-of-view shows the kiddush cup large in the fore extended toward him by the Rabbi beaming above. His own hand rises into frame to grasp the kiddush cup. The congregation starts Adon Olam.

dialogues.speaker: A DOOR
dialogues.text: Creaking open. The cut has snapped off the robust Adon Ol leaving sepulchral quiet. DANNY, clutching his kiddush cup, hesitantly enters the d Minda's elderly eastern European gatekeeper closes the door behind him. Minda is an old man staring at him from behind a bare des His look, eyes magnified by thick glasses, is impossible to read. DANNY creeps to the chair facing the desk. He gingerly si the squeaking leather upholstery, self-conscious under Minda's stare. Minda breathes regularly through his mouth. It is the onl in the room. A long beat. The two sit face to face. Minda smacks his lips a couple of times, preparing to spe Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: MINDA
dialogues.text: When the truth is found. To be lies. He pauses. He clears his throat. At length: . And all the hope. Within you dies. Another beat. DANNY waits. Minda stares. He smacks his lips again. . Then what? DANNY doesn't answer. It is unclear whether the question directed at him. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 Minda clears his throat with a loud and thorough hawking. The hawking abates. Minda sniffs. . Grace Slick. Marty Balin. Paul Kanta. Jorma... somethin. These are the membas of the Airplane. He nods a couple of times. . Interesting. He reaches up and slowly opens his desk drawer. He takes out. He lays it on the bare desk and pushes it partway across. . Here. It is DANNY's radio. . Be a good boy.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: LARRY is at his desk sorting through mail. Arlen Finkle (off DANNY was magnificent. LARRY looks up: Arlen is leaning in his accustomed spot i office doorway.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh. Thank you, Arlen. Arlen Finkle Mazel tov. It was wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes it was. Thank you. Arlen Finkle Such a time of nachas, LARRY. He's your youngest. You have to savor it.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: I do. I will. Arlen Finkle See you at the staff caf.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes. Arlen shoves off to go, but hesitates. Arlen Finkle I just... I shouldn't tell you. I'm not telling you offic The tenure candidates aren't notified til Monday.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . Yes? Arlen nods. Arlen Finkle You'll be very pleased. LARRY stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Arlen. Over his back as he goes: Arlen Finkle I didn't say anything. Mazel tov.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: Distant thunder at the cut. We are tracking behind Minda's female Caliban as she walk the hall, stooped and shuffling. She holds a stack of papers in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 132 Mail in front of him. He opens an envelope from RONALD MESHBESHER, ESQ. In it are two pieces of paper. Topmost is a letter headed AGREEMENT. Underneath is an invoice. The amount: $3,000. Arriving rain begins to patter at the window.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL CLASS
dialogues.text: The TEACHER, Mar King, leads the class in drill. DANNY has a book tilted towards him on his desktop. It hi his radio. The door opens and the elderly woman shuffles to Mar King She hands him a paper from off her stack of copies. Mar King puts on reading glasses and inspects it. As he r thunder crashes, closer.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: He fingers the invoice. Close on a printed detail: PAYABLE: and, typed underneath Receipt. Wind is whipping rain hard against the window.

dialogues.speaker: HEBREW SCHOOL CLASS
dialogues.text: Mar King taps on the desktop for attention. Mar King Chaverim, there's a tornado warning from the weather service. Rabbi Minda has decided to move us over to the basement of the shul. Hubbub in the classrooom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 133 . Shechet. Shechet. We're gonna form two lines. This is orderly. Hakol b'seder.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: He is staring down at his desktop. Thunder. He reaches up and scratches his nose as he stares at his On the desk: a ledger sheet with a list of students' name to each name, a grade. LARRY drums his fingers. He picks up a pencil. He goes down to PARK, CLIVE. Next to it is an F. He waggles the pencil, eraser-end thumping the sheet. He erases the F. He enters a C. The pencil leaves frame. We hold for a beat on the new gr The hand reenters. It puts a minus sign after the C. The hand withdraws. LARRY closes the file. Just as he does so: The phone jangles, very harsh. LARRY looks at it, frozen. He lets it ring a couple times. He reaches for it. He slowly picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . Yes?

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Hi, Len Shapiro.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Oh. Hello Dr. Shapiro. Dr. Shapiro Listen, mazel tov on DANNY.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you. Dr. Shapiro Listen, could you come in to discuss these X-ray results? LARRY sits frozen, phone to his ear. . Hello?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: Yes? Dr. Shapiro LARRY, could you come in and discuss these X-ray results? Remember the X-rays we took?

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: . We can't discuss them on the phone? Thunder. Pattering rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 135 Dr. Shapiro I think we'd be more comfortable in person. Can you come in? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY
dialogues.text: When? Dr. Shapiro Now. Now is good. I've cleared some time now.

dialogues.speaker: TALMUD TORAH PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: The students mill about. It is overcast dark, and extreme Someone is fumbling with keys at the shul. DANNY still has his radio with the earpiece in. Everyone's clothing flaps. Ronnie Nudell shouts above the wind: Ronnie Nudell That fucking flag is gonna rip right off the flagpole!

dialogues.speaker: CAR
dialogues.text: We are looking through a windshield lashed by rain at LAR driving. His hands are clenched tight on the wheel. Wipers pump to keep up with rain. The cars behind have their lights on. It has gotten quite dark. Passing streetlights rhythmically sweep LARRY's face, the stippled and bent by the rain on the windows.

dialogues.speaker: TALMUD TORAH PARKING LOT
dialogues.text: DANNY is looking across the lot in which orange school bu are parked. His head bobs in time to the music. His hair whips in the wind. A build roar, very deep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136 We hear, very compressed, the beginning of "Somebody to L DANNY sees a shaggy-haired youth among the milling studen

dialogues.speaker: DANNY
dialogues.text: Hey! Fagle! From behind DANNY, over his shoulder: we see a funnel clo the middle distance. A growing rumble. The tornado is approaching. At the first downbeat of its chorus the Jefferson Airplan bumps up full. We cut to black, and credits.
